}} 'Harvey Washington Wiley' (October 18, 1844 â June 30, 1930) was a noted
chemist best known for his leadership in the passage of the landmark Pure Food
and Drug Act of 1906 and his subsequent work at the Good Housekeeping Institute
laboratories. He was the first commissioner of the US Food and Drug
Administration. He was awarded the Elliott Cresson Medal of The Franklin
Institute in 1910.
